learnings.title: Building Ethos: Expertise, Reliability, Benevolence
learnings.bodyMd:
# Building Ethos: Expertise, Reliability, Benevolence

## Overview
Trust rests on three pillars: demonstrated expertise, consistent reliability, and benevolent intent. Signal each explicitly.

## Key Concepts
- Expertise: relevant experience, credentials, results.
- Reliability: follow‑through, responsiveness, accuracy.
- Benevolence: alignment with others’ interests, not just your own.
- Proof over claims: show, don’t tell.

## Examples
- Expertise: link to 2 case studies with metrics.
- Reliability: clear SLAs and on‑time updates.
- Benevolence: propose options that trade off in their favor.

## Common Pitfalls
- Over‑claiming without evidence.
- Promising beyond capacity, then missing commitments.

## Summary
State qualifications briefly, prove reliability with behaviors, and prioritize the audience’s goals to earn durable trust.

learnings.title: Proof Stack: Evidence Hierarchy
learnings.bodyMd:
# Proof Stack: Evidence Hierarchy

## Overview
Sequence the strongest forms of proof first to accelerate belief and reduce perceived risk.

## Key Concepts
- Hierarchy: third‑party validation > customer references > controlled pilots > internal data > opinion.
- Relevance: same industry, role, and scale beats generic logos.
- Triangulation: combine 2–3 proofs for robustness.

## Examples
- Open with a credentialed audit, then peer reference quotes, then your pilot metrics.
- For a policy, cite legal guidance, benchmark peers, and internal risk analyses.

## Common Pitfalls
- Logo dumping without outcomes.
- Leading with weak, anecdotal proof.

## Summary
Lead with your strongest independent proof, then layer complementary evidence that matches the audience’s risk model.

learnings.title: Transparent Risk and Uncertainty Communication
learnings.bodyMd:
# Transparent Risk and Uncertainty Communication

## Overview
Transparent communication about risks and unknowns increases credibility and supports joint problem solving.

## Key Concepts
- Risk framing: likelihood × impact, with mitigations.
- Unknowns: what’s uncertain, what we’re doing to learn.
- Range estimates: best/base/worst case with triggers.
- Shared ownership: co‑created mitigation plans.

## Examples
- Roadmap changes: list risks, signals, and contingency steps.
- Pilot plans: define success thresholds and kill criteria.

## Common Pitfalls
- Hand‑waving uncertainties to look confident.
- Over‑indexing on optimism with no contingencies.

## Summary
Name real risks and unknowns. Propose concrete mitigations and decision triggers to build confidence and autonomy.

learnings.title: Consistency, Follow‑Through, and Reputation Signals
learnings.bodyMd:
# Consistency, Follow‑Through, and Reputation Signals

## Overview
Reputation compounds from consistent, visible behaviors. Make reliability legible and easy to verify.

## Key Concepts
- Operating cadence: predictable updates and checkpoints.
- Decisions log: record agreements and outcomes.
- External signals: certifications, reviews, community contributions.
- Responsiveness: SLAs for replies and actions.

## Examples
- Weekly progress notes with risks and next steps.
- Public changelog and status page for services.

## Common Pitfalls
- Sporadic updates that force stakeholders to chase.
- Hiding issues until they explode.

## Summary
Make reliability observable: set cadences, keep promises, and surface evidence of consistency.

learnings.title: Repairing Trust After Mistakes
learnings.bodyMd:
# Repairing Trust After Mistakes

## Overview
When things go wrong, swift ownership and concrete repair plans can strengthen trust.

## Key Concepts
- Acknowledgment: name the impact without defensiveness.
- Apology: concise, specific, no excuses.
- Remedy: immediate actions, longer‑term fixes, verification.
- Follow‑up: confirm outcomes and invite feedback.

## Examples
- Incident post‑mortem with clear owners and timelines.
- Customer‑facing apology with make‑good options.

## Common Pitfalls
- Vague apologies that dodge responsibility.
- Promising fixes without capacity or dates.

## Summary
Own the issue, fix it, and close the loop. Trust often rebounds higher with transparent, competent recovery.
